prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC 6872
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: NGC 6872 and IC 4970 is a 1:5 galaxy merger at 65 Mpc. The ongoing star formation has been studied not only in the optical, but also in NIR and Halpha.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Studying the spatial distribution of Giant Molecular Gas Clouds in an ongoing merger requires not only high spatial resolution, but also large spatial coverage. Albeite hampered by a much lower spatial resolution previous Halpha observations have revealed that the gas in this merger is concentrated in the tidal features and the spiral arms of NGC 6872, whereas the central region of both galaxies is almost gas free. Additional optical data reveal that almost all Young Massive Clusters are also found within those spiral arms and tidal tails. Therefore, the proposed observations will focus on the spiral arms and tidal tails of NGC 6872 as well, using the position of the confirmed YMC. To allow for the resolution of GMGC with a median radius of ~20 pc, we require an angular resolution og 0.2 arcsec, for each of the 14 individual pointings.
Sensitivity: Numerical simulations show that newly formed star clusters lose up to 50% of their mass in the first 3 Gyr after their formation. Assuming a mean Globular Cluster mass of 10^5 solar masses we therefore need to detect GMGC with a mass of ~ 10^6 solar masses to not only form stars, but also to guarantee the survival of the star cluster and eventually become what we call a Globular Cluster. We chose the CO J=3-2 line given that it is the best tracer for high density gas. For a S/N=7 and a line width of 50 km/sec we derive the required sensitivity per pointing to be 0.3 mJy. The time on source for each of the 14 pointings is 4.53 min. Including standard calibrations and all overheads the total execution time for this target is 2.66 h. The overheads of 34 min exceeds the 30%, but due to the required large number of pointings and their alignment with the tidal tails this can not be avoided.

The NGC 4567/ NGC 4568 merger is the closest of the 3 targets and represents an early stadium of the merger. However, a prominent dust lane at the apparent intersection region suggest that both galaxies are indeed physically connected. Given the morphology of the merger we require 15 individual pointings positioned in the overlapping region and the leading tidal tails. The required angular resolution is also 0.2 arcsec, which given its distance corresponds to ~18 pc. Due to the fact that the merger has started only approximatelly 200-300 million years ago we expect the molecular clouds to be not only smaller, but also less massive, i.e. in the range of 5*10^5 solar masses. Therefore we request a sensitivity of 0.34 mJy for each of the 15 selected pointings. This results in an on-source time of 1.5 min per pointing and a total execution time of 1.1 hours. The large number of of short pointings is the result of the high angular resolution, covering the overlapping region, which results in a large total overhead. However, if we are to follow the the distrubution of the molecular gas in great detail the spatial resolution can not be reduced.

Similar to the previous two targets the resolution of the indivudual molecular clouds requires a high angular resolution of 0.2 arcsec, corresponding to 24 pc in the IC 2163/NGC 2207 merger. To study the distribution of the high density gass clouds of 10^6 solar masses in the overlapping region of the merger we require 15 individual pointings. These will focus on the overlap region, for which previous H1 and CO maps find increased star formation. In order to reach a mass resolution of 10^6 solar masses with a S/N=7 for the CO J=3-2 line with a line width of 27 km/sec (broadest possible line width) we request a sensitivity of 0.43 mJy for each pointing. This results in a exposure time for each pointing of 1 min and a total execution time of 54 min.

In order to study the distribution of the dense molecular gas we will target the tidal tails of this merger, using an angular resolution of 0.2 arcsec, to resolve structure of severeal tens of parsec. Our mass limit is 10^6 solar masses , which for the CO J=3-2 line, a S/N=7 results in a sensitivity of 0.3 mJy. For each of the 15 individual pointings following the tidal tails this will require an on-target time of 2.08 min and a total execution time of 1.34 hours.

The NGC 474 is an example for a well advanced merger, with a single core resembeling an early-type galaxy, but a prominent shell structure. To study the effects of the previous merger processes and ongoing interaction with NGC 470 we will observe the HI bridge between NGC 474 and NGC 470, as well as the one of the inner shells detected around NGC 474. To allow fo gas clouds of 5*0.10^5 solar masses to be detected with a S/N=7 we request a sensitivity of 0.34 mJy for each of the 15 selected pointings. This results in an on-source time of 1.4 min per pointing and a total execution time of 1.1 h.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to conduct a survey on gas rich galaxy mergers, including NGC 4567/NGC 4568, NGC 2207/IC 2163, NGC 6872/IC 4970, NGC 7252, and NGC 474/ NGC 470 and study the distribution of the molecular gas probed by the CO J=3-2 line, using ALMA in the extended configuration in Band 7. The aim is to detect Giant Molecular Gas Clouds (GMGCs) as the birth places of Young Massive Clusters and compare their spatial distribution and mass.. As gas rich mergers are a possible scenario to form massive early-type galaxies, which are known to host the most numerous Globular Cluster Systems, we will be able to study the early phases of the formation of those Globular Cluster Systems. Searching for GMGCs in mergers with different mass ratios between the two merging galaxies and at different stages is essential to understand, why we find early-type galaxies to be more diverse than previously thought, i.e. varying significantly in their stellar populations and morphology.
